WSC-Category 1 Collaborative: A surface water management framework to counterbalance groundwater withdrawals in wetter regions of the U.S.

The over-use of groundwater is becoming a critical problem in regions historically characterized by abundant rainfall and surface water, including much of the U.S. Northern Gulf and Southern Atlantic Coastal regions. This project proposes to develop a theoretical framework and a new modeling/decision support tool aimed at better managing surface water so that it can be used to close groundwater supply gaps. The proposed management framework focuses on understanding human-water-land use interactions, with an emphasis on agriculture. The research team will explore the potentially transformative concept of integrating the social and biophysical dimensions of water systems into a unified framework for improved management of surface water resources. This includes consideration of the balance between water demand for humans and ecosystems. 

The project team will develop an innovative geospatial decision support/modeling tool that can identify and evaluate opportunities to capture and use surface water to replace groundwater in these wetter regions of the US. The theoretical framework and associated geospatial decision support tool will be unique for wetter regions of the U.S. where groundwater and surface water have traditionally been managed separately and surface water management has focused largely on flood control. The tool will directly benefit farmers, land managers, regulatory agencies, and state and local government officials. The research will be integrated with education through a trans-disciplinary senior/MS-level course at UL Lafayette. Public outreach, focusing on water conservation efforts, will be part of this course. The project will additionally leverage and expand existing NSF and NOAA watershed-based education/outreach projects that target graduate students and high school teachers, respectively. This project also serves as a catalyst for developing a new collaborative team of researchers interested in water sustainability.

por.por_cntn:
Despite abundant average annual rainfall and frequent flooding in the southeastern part of the United States, many regions near the Gulf Coast are greatly over-using groundwater resources. The loss of groundwater near our coastlines is causing some areas to subside or sink and is leading to the inland encroachment of seawater. The goal of our project was to develop a geospatial model to understand human-water-land use interactions in the southeast U.S. for the purpose of identifying new water management strategies that can conserve groundwater and reduce flooding risks.

Our work has been transformative in shifting the way we think about water management in these systems. Our results suggest that water management strategies should focus on capturing and using excess surface water to substitute and possibly replinish groundwater. Specific advancements include the development of original methods and tools to calculate water stress on the watershed scale and on monthly to annual scales. This detailed level of information is required for informing water management decisions. We also developed a novel approach for incorporating the impact of water quality problems, specifically salt water intrusion, into the analysis of water stress. All of our analytical approaches for water resource assessment have been published in open-access journals. Our work also focused on unraveling what social and economic factors have driven the overuse of groundwater. This included in-person surveys with more than seventy members of the rice farming community in Louisiana to determine what factors drive their choices regarding groundwater use versus surface water use. The results reinforced what we learned from the physical analysis in that large water stresses, caused mainly by dry periods and drought, led to the installation of more groundwater wells rather than spurring new investments in surface water capture and storage. In response to these findings we expanded our work to construct an original framework for evaluating the suitability of new water management strategies in the Gulf Coast region. We specifically focused on Aquifer Storage and Recovery (ASR), which is a method where excess surface water is gathered, treated, and then pumped into the underlying groundwater systems for storage. This management technique can potentially address some flooding issues while enhancing the sustainability of our coastal aquifer systems. Using the new suitability analysis tool, we have identified watersheds where ASR would be a particularly good investment.

Our project also catalyzed the creation of an interdisciplinary team of researchers from disciplines including biology, geology, civil engineering, architecture and design, sociology, and economics to work on this critical water problem in the Gulf Coast. We engaged over a dozen stakeholder groups throughout the project, including many state and federal government agencies, as well as non-government organizations such as the Nature Conservancy. We also focused on workforce development by training 12 graduate students, one postdoc, and several undergraduate students over the course of our project. Seven MS-degree theses and one PhD dissertation were competed. More than 50% of the students in our group were female and two were from underrepresented groups. Results from our work have been disseminated widely through almost 50 presentations at local, regional, and national conferences, as well as the publication of 10 peer-reviewed journal articles. We were also able to integrate our research into educational initiatives throughout our project, including the creation of an architectural design course that focused on designing site-specific water management strategies for rice farms in Louisiana.
